Reggie White was an advocate for many things, including being against against homosexuality. He made more than one public admonition over it, and no doubt his death will be celebrated by gay rights activists. But he made far more public statements about other things, and he is also living proof that the tendency of gay rights people to paint a person entirely by his or stance on gay rights is flawed. In fact, most ministers who speak out against homosexuality are very humanitarian people who genuinely care about others, as was in the case of White. There are exceptions of course, as in the case of the corrupt preacher Fred Phelps, whom most of the chuch doesn't accept anyway. 
 
 A minister who cares about society and wants to see it be less "sinful" cannot be expected to give homosexuality a pass. But the irony is, while gay rights people vilified White trying to label him a homohater in the wake of statements about homosexuality, the issue of homosexuality was peripheral for him. Judging White or anyone else by their opinions of homosexuality is like judging gay rights people themselves on a single issue we don't like about them, instead of taking their message as a whole and weighing it. Most people have things in their lives we may not agree with or like, but we have to look at their lives as a whole. 
 
 What of the humanitarian gestures on White's part?
 
 What of the times he counseled and helped others?
 
 Are we to throw those out the window because of one issue? Are we to thow out the humanitarian getures of mother Teresa just because she was associated with a homophobic organzation (the Catholic Church)? How about James Dobson, who spends far more time dealing with children issues and husband/wife problems than homosexuality?
 
 Gay rights people would love for the world to be seen through one single filter: the issue of who likes homosexuality and who doesn't. They seem to want people to be judged on it. As if the world revolved on their one pet issue. It's ironic that most people denigrated by the gay lobby because of their oppostion to homosexuality are usually people who are far more concerned about other social ills such as poverty, divorce, etc. Homosexuality is usually not even the subject of much of their time and attention.
 
 So my advice to the gay lobby: get some tolerance. Not everyone has to see things your way, and even if they don't, it doesn't, by any means, make them a bigot. Before leveling that charge, check out the whole of their life and message.
